Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 11:02AM - edited Oct 24, 2011 11:03AM by thats-life- hey joanne. I know it hasnt been long since your diagnosis. I know I was someone who didnt want to see reports or scans for the first 6 months. I only recently asked for copies. We are all different, but do it if you are ready. In Australia PET's are not routine in the public health system. They wont give me one. My oncs relied on a bone scan, a CT, and finally a spinal MRI to give me a stage IV diagnosis. They wont do a bone biopsy either. They were going to, on my rib, but the angle they were to go in on to hit it was too dangerous....thats what they said anyway. Dont knock yourself for not having all the info yet, though it is good to become more proactive in treatment discussions and more informed on options and our own pathology, it takes a little time to get your head around it all, but as CB said, we are here to help work through it with you if you want. Im wondering if you have been given treatment similar to an earlier stage BC, because your mets are limited?...anyway, wishing you every success with treatment and your next appointment joanne :)

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 01:55AM thats-life- wrote: Hi Cate, I remember the feelings you are going through, it was a rollercoaster ride through many emotions, but it mellowed, after about 3 months i found calm.. and a place to 'be' in my mind where i could deal with life while i came to terms with this big change to my reality. At first, to help me deal with the panic, i made a 'panic book'.. words that made me feel strong, or reminded me of the big picture, i would read them when i felt panic, or fear creeping in to my mind. it helped to remind myself that i have time, which is more than many people in the world get, with wars, earthquakes etc.  I have found that avoiding this reality for a few days is quite nice every so often! It seems i have many days now where im just living. I wouldnt have believed that i could do that when dxd nearly 2 yrs ago. Its not an easy road, but it has opened my mind and heart. I have bone mets only. At first the oncs were seeing me every month. At my last appointment he said 'see you in 6 months'....i was like 'huh!?'... learning to live each day, in the true sense of that saying, is something we can achieve, we kind of have to! :) be gentle on yourself x

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 05:34PM thats-life- wrote: chele, i have extensive bone mets. I think there was a little progression early into my starting treatment, but they are stable now a year into treatment. I asked my onc whether my met sites are in danger of fracture etc...she said "i would not be worried about fractures at this time'..i havent asked yet if they are lytic or blastic, but i will next time. when i thought recently that there had been progression (due to pain increase at mets sites) the onc suggested i start zoladex, to help cover the tamox in case it has stopped working, then she set up an appt for an ooph, and I would go straight onto a AI...scans showed that tamox is still working, so i have put that plan on hold,. Onc wanted me to get an ooph out of the way while i am still reasonably 'well'...being ER+ PR+ you could consider this option?, though im not sure of your history :) but good luck, i hope the next one brings you back to stable :)

Posts.Title: Help, Im boring. Cant talk about anything but cancer. LivingIt Reneepals

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 01:46PM thats-life- wrote: i spoke to my good friend about this yesterday. Said i was glad i wasnt the only one who finds others are not interested in this disease, and in me.. She asked me if I was very interested in cancer before my dx?..would I have wanted to talk about it as a subject before my dx?..i said 'no'..but then i didnt know much about cancer. I said to her that if i knew then what i know now, if we were taught in school how cancer works, (as one in two Australians will get it) how it mutates, travels, goes back to sleep, how it is still a mystery to the medical world in a way, and how food and exercise change the way our bodies work, about immune systems, and how common cancer is...then i think it would be a much more interesting subject to others. I realised cancer is still a scary word because the general public still dont know the facts. Even i didnt after my dx...I was told 'you will feel tired', but not why. I was told nothing about how to live with this common disease. There may be good advertising campaigns to scare people about cancer, but none to educate. it took alot of self education this last year to undertsand my disease to the best of my ability. No, I dont want to talk about trivial shit any more. I want to talk about big things. Like the universe, microbiology, love, funding for MBC research, study results on mice, on women with BC, macrophages...and because of that, no one asks me over for coffee any more. (lol) p.s. finished "the Emporer of all Maladies" a few weeks ago...amazing book... Had me in tears.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 01:17AM thats-life- wrote: hi thisisme, wow, big decisions....as i read through your post and everyone's replies, i was thinking toronto! toronto!, but it is something i cant give advice on,  you know in your heart what to do, as we all do...but i can give you a little of my experience...i am doing it alone with my 13 yr old daughter. though i have a friend who is staying with me by chance, but she works in the city and is gone 12+ hrs a day...i have found peace by encouraging my daughter's friendships, even if it exhausts me, knowing they will be her support later, treatment for me is just tamox, so very doable, apart from a few months of hot flushes etc. sometimes im in pain, but i get through. in australia we can hook in with palliative care, even if we are not at end stage of stage IV. i did so, and now have access to home help if i need it, someone to do the groceries (though im going to start shopping online)...the thing is, you need help with the kids, and in my opinion, our kids need some happiness, and a break from the stress of our disease sometimes, and your friends/their friends can offer that...is there a community nurse to help if you are unwell? and if they will be living there in the future, well, its up to you, but st*ff the sadness and lonliness, change can be a good thing...maybe, you will find someone to hold your head when puking, i hope so...and there are volunteer drivers etc, maybe look into your options in the area you are thinking of returning to?..lastly, remember...we can do yrs with this disease, so dont lose hope, but you remind me of me, planning ahead...i hope you all find some happiness again :)

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 05:44PM - edited Sep 27, 2011 07:30PM by thats-life- When i was 13 my mum was diagnosed with cancer, and i lost faith..living with the realities of life at a young age does change us. You will have a deeper understanding of life, and people, because of this journey. You may not get on so well with those who have had no real pain, but you will have deeper connections with those you meet and connect with in the future. Right now you are learning some amazing things about life and love. These experiences and memories can help build your resilience to the minor things that stump alot of people, you may not be aware right now of your strength and compassion, but we can see it, and those you meet on your journey will see it :) You have a life to plan too, keep your dreams going, even if they are put on hold for now. Keep a diary of your dreams, goals and plans. Please reach out to others who have seen this deeper side of life...whether online, and here, or through a group for children who have a parent with cancer. They exist!...take care, n.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 09:12AM thats-life- wrote: me too.. susan mentioned choosing your tasks. I was told about this at a 'living with cancer' program. An occupational therapist was a guest speaker. She said we can make appointments with an occupational therapist associated with the cancer center, where their priority is to establish what we most loved doing before MBC, and what we want to do while living with MBC. They can help us identify where we are losing our minimal daily energy reserve (as cancer cells use up alot of our daily energy) and how to change our lives so that we can enjoy and get satisfaction in what is most important to us. Hence if you love cooking, they can organise someone to shop for you. If you like to take a little walk with the family, have others do the housework....as far as forgetting things...yep, i have done that, do it alot actually...dont know how to fix that one :)

Honestly, i think its the Australian culture of each man for himself...stiff upper lip...gotta be tough that has us breaking eventually. I also have realised how hard it actually is to access resources here. Even at stage IV, its still the spanish inquisition to get even a litlle help from the cancer foundations or the government. Im sure you know what i mean...It is sad that it came to his suicide attempt to get help..though we are not used to reaching out in Aust., when i did i was told i didnt 'qualify' for assistance from the cancer council...I though 'what does it take to qualify???'..Im stage IV, a single parent, and big bills for my daughter's teeth, my funeral plan. Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 09:46PM - edited Jun 22, 2011 10:02PM by thats-life- hi tdmm, i remember how hesitant i was to take the first tablet. i would put it up to my mouth for a few days then put it back in the bottle. on the fourth day i said "goodbye youth! what will be will be!" out loud, and swallowed it. that night i didnt sleep much, i felt my body temperature change, had strange sensations, and the next morning woke to my new 'norm'. that evening i had my first hot flush. i decided to take the tablet at 9pm each night. i didnt have trouble sleeping, apart from waking occasionally with sweats or a flush. for a number of months i had about 6 hot flushes a day, some were full on, but they have eased off now to only occasional. i had joint pain, and bone pain, and still do, but nothing a couple of panadol wouldnt help. the bone pain was considered tumour flare. scans showed stable bone mets, and clear organs, so 9 months and counting. i dont like to jinx myself, but i cant feel the 2 tumours in my breast anymore...so i might use that as a personal gauge..my concern re uterine cancer was eased by oncs explaining that it is a very slow growing cancer, and treatable, i decided that the risk was worth it. i stay alert for dvt, clotting issues are in my family. i am so grateful for this relatively mild treatment, and hope to be on it for years..fingers crossed. these days i mainly have the little 'temple surges' as i call them, irritability, tiredness, aches and pains. I havent menstruated since the first tablet. the onc looked up in surprise the other week when i told her that (they hadnt asked)..i dont know why she looked so surprised?...wishing you success xx

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 05:36AM thats-life- wrote: Hi jpd, you wrote an interesting post, it rang some bells for me :) I think what I need most is someone to listen. We have alot to absorb, especially if we are researching alternative options as well as sifting through our conventional options. We also have alot of emotional ups and downs as we come to terms with the diagnosis. Sometimes, when people (kindly) offer information or treatment options, i need to know that there is a bunch of research behind it, and i appreciate when someone provides that research. I appreciated when my friend printed out lots of pages of info on hormonal treatments verses oopherectomy and hormonals etc, she went to the effort of finding the studies, and i was then able to read through them at my convenience. I spend alot of time researching this disease, and someone to bounce off is invaluable.  I think some of us need a wide berth, space to feel all the things we feel, and then a caring ear when we are in the mood to talk. I find i can talk till the cows come home about cancer, or treatments, but if a friend or family member want to, i get irritated, usually because i know they are discussing it from a mainstream, limited position. It is amazing how little we really know about cancer, till we get it. If i had a molecular biologist as a sister, id be at her place every day picking her brain...lol. If someone wants to refuse treatment that is their choice, and should be supported. Ask her what she would like you to send to her, and send it. My brother told me that when our mother was seriously ill, she cut off at a certain point. He said to me that dying is a very personal time, and that i may not have the inclination to be talking and sharing feelings at end stage, so to do and say what i want to NOW. It was good advice. Some of us go into our own little world when dealing with this. Its ok, its all ok. If you want to tell her how you feel about her, do it. I know i am quite an angry person now too. All anyone can do is tell me they love me, help where they can, leave me alone if i need to be alone, listen to me when i need to talk, and sometimes make me laugh. It must be tough on the outside looking in, but though she may be up and down, just have patience, and be there when she is ready, and let her know you will be there when she is ready :)

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 06:38PM thats-life- wrote: How does one define fear? where does fear fit in to deciding to research our disease, try an alternative diet protocol, look for studies that support them? is it any more 'fearful' to go to mexico for an alt vitamin treatment than it is to ask for every chemo in the arsenal even when told that it is doing more harm than good, as i see often, or to brave a phase one trial? I think fear of dying is something we all have to deal with at stage IV, it is not exclusive to those who pursue a 'natural' as opposed to 'chemical' treatment route. All treatments offered to us are potentially dangerous. No treatment offers us a cure. 'the thread', or forum that many of you avoid, is mainly full of legitimate study results, along with some questioning, a little theorising, and some simple complementary ideas to help us on our journey. We pay for standard treatment, knowing it will only give us, hopefully, more time. Some may choose to pay for Alternative treatment that (though im not sure its legal) offers the same. I find it hard to understand the hesitancy to explore all our options. You find it hard to understand why some would do that. Each to their own. I think the discussion has been exhausted on bco. If you read the latest findings linked on 'that thread'. or in the 'research' forum, you will see intriguing and potentially benficial evidence of how we may be able to influence the outcome of our disease. Lauriesh, your post was so true. I believe we would have haha'd those things 20 yrs ago.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 09:42PM - edited Aug 17, 2011 09:42PM by thats-life- I spoke to my new oral surgeon last week about this issue. in my opinion, he seemed very informed on the topic, we talked about it for at least half an hour. He said that there is a 10% chance of ONJ from a dental procedure if on zometa. Less than 1% chance on an oral bisphosphonate. I discussed this with him because i have a friend who was diagnosed stage IV 3 years ago. in preparation for her treatment and zometa she had every tooth removed...(!)..3 weeks ago she was diagnosed with ONJ, and spent a week in hospital on I V antibiotics. He told me that there are spontaneous cases of ONJ on zometa. unrelated to a dental procedure. To my mind, this means that the risk is there, whether we proceed with dental extraction or not. My previous oral surgeon claimed that it would take a year or so for bisphosphonates to create the enviroment where ONJ was an issue, but he used scare tactics by showing me pics of ONJ...I prefer my new oral surgeon, who discusses the pros and cons and is honest about the risks. I would consult with an oral surgeon who is informed on this concern. good luck with what you decide :)

When pushed, my regular onc admitted that PET's were not offered in the public health system here, and again if i wanted one i could push for it and pay for it. They will only do a PET when it is important to look further into a particular area that is of concern on another scan, so she said. So it seems to me, at least in Australia, that the basic standard approach is bone scans and CT scans, and 'wait' for any measurable lesions elsewhere to show on those scans, or else when we present with symptoms, investigate then.....i know it can be frustrating. I suppose we have to decide how aggressive we want to be re detecting things as early as possible, and how much we want to self advocate and self fund scans...thats how i see it anyway. My recent bone scan result was 'stable disease, no changes since feb'...i asked the onc if my extensive spinal mets only showed on MRI, how do we know they are stable too?...he said " well, we can order another MRI down the track and check that, yes"    hmmmm... MRI's  are costly, either to the health system, or us, and you may have to push for one, as i am going to do, but i may have to pay for it..  im not sure if your onc was correct to say that bone stability would be a good indicator of soft tissue organ stability??...im sure there are people here who have had progression to soft tissue organs with stable bone disease....?

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2012 08:38AM thats-life- wrote: Chickadee: the first study link was very vague. It reported a higher risk of death with no systemic treatment. But it did not specify chemotherapy as the systemic treatment used in comparison to no treatment in the study. The second study link you added, used phone calls from a clinic to accumulate it's results. Again, not the most comprehensive study I have come across. Daughterneedsadvice: Your mum should make her own decision, after listening to the advice of her oncologist, and asking the RIGHT questions of her oncologist. She needs to ask for her particular potential overall survival benefit from doing the next chemo option, and the following one too. She needs to decide if the potential benefit, including possible side effects outweighs her quality of life queries, as she has had a number of chemotherapy treatments. She can then make an informed decision. I think asking for medical decision advice on a discussion board predominantly used by those going through standard treatment is something one should only do with an awareness that these are opinions of lay people only, most of whom have chosen to use palliative chemotherapy. There are a large number of studies that show a low carb diet can influence breast cancer, and also recently, that stress can create an environment (in the bone) that encourages cancer cell growth. Therefore focusing on relaxation can help. I would not recommend any treatment choice, as our decisions regarding our stage IV cancer diagnosis are very personal, and none have been proven to cure us of course. I wrote a list of questions to ask your oncologist, in laymans terms, as the first post in the stage IV thread in the Alternative forum here.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 07:17AM thats-life- wrote: hi jenn, i just read your post, and want you to know i hear you there..my daughter is 13, and i raised her alone ( i have a friend staying at the moment, but she works 13 hrs a day in the city) we have been getting cranky with each other alot since my dx...i try really hard to give her a 'normal' life..but sometimes i have found i need lots of space, to handle this dx, and to think, or not think...i have explained to her that the drug i am on (tamoxifen) makes me irritable, and emotional. But i dont want to take anti anxiety meds yet, or an anti depressant...i am holding out as long as i can on extra medication...though some would say this is wrong. it is right for me i think. i spoke to my onc about it, i said im not sure if im anxious, or depressed clinically ...who wouldnt be naturally a bit depressed and anxious with what we are dealing with. i told them i remember responding well to valium for a very short time in my 20's...they said, fine, if you do well on that, you can try it later down the track... re panic attacks: when i was 16 i started having them after helping my mother recover from bowel cancer..i think it was tied to that, because a panic attack would come on if we were out shopping, or if her and i were anywhere alone together. they were whopper panic attacks, hyperventilating etc...i now can see it was because while she had recovered and was feeling full of life and wanting to do everything, i was remembering how she collapsed, the times she was hospitalised, and when she was weak...so when i was alone with her, the responsibility ( in my mind) was too much, i was scared something would happen, and i was responsible....i try to ease these burdens for my daughter, i have the list of people to call on the fridge, i have plans in action for her to stay with friends if i am unwell, i have told her that she is not responsible for taking care of me if i am unwell (as much as i would like that lol) i do not want her to have the burden i had as a young girl...i am straightforward about what my body is going through, to an extent, (no prognosis info etc)....but no mystery..but the mystery, the lack of information, the 'happy face' my mother put on each morning, was scary and bewildering to me as a 13/14/15/yr old...so maybe getting a bit cranky is ok jenn?..sorry if this is too long...one more thing, after a number of years with debilitating panic attacks, i started reading/researching as much as i could on them, at around 19 yrs old. i came up with just one line i would say to myself, and it cured them, for many many years.....simple as it is, that line was ' its up to me...do i want this panic attack or not'...thats it..the realisation that I was in charge of me, had a profound impact....i hope this may help your daughter.. also, panic attacks can be nipped in the bud, contrary to popular opinion. take care jen, and sorry for the  looong post xx

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 07:22PM thats-life- wrote: I see 'fervent belief, hope, encouragement on the chemo threads. I wonder 'what mind set can set concerns aside' and embark on heavy duty chemo regimes. I see deep faith in oncologists who cant cure us, and i wonder at that. Chickadee, its not hard to understand your negative experience with an Alternative practitioner, but one's personal experience is not evidence for a theory that those who try a more natural approach to disease have had a negative experience with a doctor. Coolbreeze, you said that you know one person who went the alt route, and she died. Yet you, we, know so many women who have died using conventional medicine. some quickly, and some miraculously, live 19+ yrs at stage IV. There is no logic to that argument. I posted some very old stats on 'that thread' in the alt forum a long while ago that documented the amount of time women lived with stage IV in a time before the standard treatments offered today. Some lived that magical 19 yrs with stage IV, many just 3 yrs, some 5 yrs. with no treatment. Not so different to today's figures. Chickadee, if you overview what you are asking, questioning, and apply it to all of us, the 'mind sets' are the same. That is why i dont understand the hostility (and almost religious fervour!) directed towards those who are wanting to pursue a more natural route. Were you foolish for listening to a 'quack'?, maybe. Was i foolish to walk out of my onc's office to have yet more brain scans to be told i was clear, based on a severe rash on my neck that may have caused the enlarge lymph gland, because he didnt even bother to look at the severe rash? maybe. Questioning, researching for ourselves, advocating for ourselves is very important. But overall, we should just accept each other, and our choices, they are the same, and based on the same principals.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 07:05PM - edited Feb 5, 2012 07:12PM by thats-life- Hi to all. I joined BCO in 2010, after a Stage IV dx from the get go. Changed my user name a couple of times, at present it's a song title, best sung by Frank Sinatra :) Sometimes i worry if my user name sounds flippant, but to me, it represents the shock of diagnosis: "riding high in April, shot down in May..." and also, my determination to live as long as i can: "..each time i find myself, flat on my face, I pick myself up and get back in the race!"..... I have a 13 year old daughter, who is very pretty, a bit of a maths whizz, and very social. I am 47, 48 in June!..I am tired alot, but live with minimal pain from extensive bone mets...strange. I have mets in my skull, my hip, spine, rib, and acitabulum (wrong spelling im sure). I have researched this disease exhaustively, and have decided that i want to try and influence the outcome by changing my diet, and my lifestyle. I have been in some heated debates here on BCO, but I am even grateful for them!...because they sharpened my reasoning skills, forced me to define my own beliefs and principals to myself, taught me to be critical. For that I am very grateful. I like the person I am now, much more than the person i was prior to this diagnosis. I confront life and death now, I tell people I love them, I have reignited my passion for painting in oils. My goal is to live until my child is an adult. 20 maybe?....I think I can do it :) oh, p.s. 17 months stable on Tamoxifen..I said no to Zometa. so bones are going solo.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 09:18PM - edited Oct 29, 2011 09:27PM by thats-life- i dont want to hijack this thread either...but I think it was me coolbreeze was mentioning just now ....I have seen this issue surfacing a bit lately. I have realised that in a way Im an outsider too...here i come bla bla bla ing all over the boards...and i thought to myself yesterday..how would i feel if i was a member of a bc community in Aus, and some chick from another country came there telling us all what to do...as i sometimes do...so i realised im lucky to have the acceptance i do have, from those who like me here, and hence wanted to reinforce my gratitude... coolbreeze, sometimes you are very opinionated! lol.. and i dont always agree with you...but i get what you are saying here. But.. its a fine line i suppose with us stage IV people. I have found ssdealer's posts always to be very supportive, and caring. It was just one post of yours ssd, which I responded to, that offended me (just a little bit)..(and maybe made you think i am one of the people that thinks carers shouldnt post here...which isnt true) .I think the fine line is when someone may come across as complaining about how hard it is for them, as opposed to how hard it is for the person with cancer. They probably dont mean to sound like that at all...it IS very hard for them!!!!...but its sometimes hard to hear about that, as you say coolbreeze, when we are doing our best to help ourselves and each other every day...Bernicky and many carers are incredible, informative, and have alot of support and deservedly so. When a young person comes here frightened about what their parent is going through, i sometimes try to help, imagining my daughter coming here for help...and what i would want her to be hearing from us. So it is a very, very fine line. And i suppose sometimes we are touchy at stage IV when we are in a fearful mood, or phase, or feel unwell, or if we are just pi**sed off....all i want to say is that i can and do offer my support as much as possible, im sorry if i made anyone feel unwelcome...I hope all can find what they need here....as i have....lleddick...all the best while you are going through this hard time.

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2011 07:13PM - edited Dec 5, 2011 07:34PM by thats-life- Hi apple, just have to add that nobody  has to do chemo. Stage IV choices are different yet again, as are choices at all stages, and all ages: Ian Olver, Clinical Director, Royal Adelaide Hospital Cancer Centre, Director, Medical Oncology, Royal Adelaide Hospital, and Clinical Professor, Department of Medicine, University of Adelaide, Adelaide ....'Some cancers may behave differently in the elderly and warrant different treatment approaches from those in younger patients. In breast cancer for example, the risk of local recurrence after lumpectomy declines with age. This may decrease the need for postoperative radiotherapy in older women. In the Oxford meta-analysis adjuvant chemotherapy was associated with decreasing survival benefit with increasing age particularly in the over 70 age group. Individual older women at high risk of recurrence, however, may obtain some benefit from adjuvant systemic therapy. ' Summary 'Elderly patients with advanced cancer must be allowed to balance the potential risks and benefits of treatment when deciding whether or not to have chemotherapy. The response rates to aggressive chemotherapy are similar in younger and older patients. Disease-related survival is often similar, although the older age group has more deaths due to comorbid illnesses. Factors complicating chemotherapy in the elderly are the physiological changes of ageing, the presence of comorbidities and polypharmacy. Deterioration in renal or hepatic function may force the doses of chemotherapy to be adjusted. Organ toxicities may be more problematic in the elderly, but in most tumours, the efficacy of chemotherapy is not age dependent. Chemotherapy, where indicated for advanced cancer, can therefore be safely and effectively used in selected elderly patients.' .........'For each patient the decision whether or not to have cytotoxic chemotherapy for advanced cancer is a balance between the potential benefits and adverse effects. Both of these involve value judgements by individual patients. The perspective of older patients may differ from that of younger patients. Short-term quality of life and the ability to continue managing their activities of daily living may be more important than a modest survival advantage when deciding whether to accept chemotherapy. Conversely, some fit older patients may seek aggressive chemotherapy if they can expect a similar outcome to younger patients.'

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 05:18PM - edited Dec 26, 2011 04:33PM by thats-life- Dave. You have Christmas. Your children will have this Christmas. I send you some of the strength I use to get through this special time of the year. Make memories, that's all any of us have. My gift to you both: "To see a world in a grain of sand, and heaven in a wildflower, hold infinity in the palm of your hand, and eternity in an hour"     William Blake and this: " As long as we can love each other, and remember the feeling of love we had, we can die without ever really going away. All the love you created is still there. You live on in the hearts of everyone you have touched and nurtured while you were here. Death ends a life, not a relationship" Unknown Authour. Dave, this Christmas my daughter only has me. But she remembers the love of my mother. She feels loved, even though I am the only family member in her life now. I think about how she is going to be when I die too. I have to believe she will thrive, and be ok. The only gift I can give her now is to nurture strength, independence, and give her as much happiness and laughter as i can. Its tough, but every time she is driving me nuts with her all night giggling with her friends, I remember that she deserves this laughter. When the fears of the future creep into my mind, I remind myself of the human ability to adapt, and survive. It will be ok. Send my love and best wishes for a special Christmas to your wife, and tell her I will be thinking of her. This helped me too: (wriiten by a woman living with stage IV cancer) "Your job is straightforward: Identify your children's physical and emotional needs as they arise and change, and make sure that they are satisfied" Their main emotional need is to know there is a plan, and that they will be taken care of. Thinking of you both, n.
